item.title: Simple Messaging in .NET With Redis Pub/Sub
item.description: Redis is a popular choice for caching data, but its capabilities go far beyond that. One of its lesser-known features is Pub/Sub support. Redis channels offer an interesting approach for implementing real-time messaging in your .NET applications.

item.title: Evolving Languages Faster with Type Tailoring
item.description: Programming languages are too slow! I’m not talking about execution speed—I’m talking about evolution speed. Programmers are always building new libraries and embedded DSLs, but the host programming language—particularly its type system—doesn’t understand the domain-specific aspects of these things.

item.title: A plea for the lost practice of information architecture
item.description: How the Winchester Mystery house shows us what we risk if we conflate agile with constant bottom-up iteration and don't do any information architecture.

item.title: Why Attend Programming Conferences?
item.description: I'm sitting on a barely delayed1 train on my way back from PyCon '24 in Berlin. This was the second time I attended an industry/programming conference, after attending JupyterCon last year. This year I had to convince my manager to get the greenlight to go, so I thought I would write down my thoughts about why it's worth going to conferences and how I can convince my manager next year.
item.author: (Haakon Hals Rød)

item.title: Schema migrations: pitfalls and risks | Changing the schema on the production database and live traffic should be easy with zero downtime. You should be able to preserve backward compatibility for all clients, even if they have hardcoded assumptions about schema and can’t easily upgrade them.
item.description: At Quesma we help customers to innovate faster by re-shaping the way applications are built and connected to their DBs. Quesma database gateway enables development teams to modernise and evolve application architecture.

item.title: How I Use Git Worktrees
item.description: There are a bunch of posts on the internet about using git worktree command. As far as I can tell, most of them are primarily about using worktrees as a replacement of, or a supplement to git branches. Instead of switching branches, you just change directories. This is also how I originally had used worktrees, but that didn't stick, and I abandoned them. But recently worktrees grew on me, though my new use-case is unlike branching.

item.title: The Computer Genius the Communists Couldn’t Stand
item.description: In 1970s Poland, Jacek Karpiński created a computer which could conduct a million operations per second and was small enough to fit into a briefcase. At a time when computers were not only slower but also comparable in size to cupboards, this was a remarkable accomplishment. Unfortunately, the communist regime blocked the device.
item.author: (Author: Marek KępaShare:FacebookTwitter)

item.title: The Memento Design Pattern in C#, Practically With Examples [2024]
item.description: Discover how to implement the Memento design pattern in C# to create user-friendly applications with undo and redo functionalities, enhancing user experience and boosting your app’s robustness.

item.title: Developers want more, more, more: the 2024 results from Stack Overflow’s Annual Developer Survey - Stack Overflow
item.description: In May of 2024, we opened up the 14th annual Stack Overflow Developer Survey to technologists worldwide—and the results are in! This year, technologies such as JavaScript and PostgreSQL remain most popular, Rust and Markdown remain most admired, developers are most frustrated by technical debt at work, and they don’t see AI as a threat to their jobs. Themes we see in this year’s survey results show us that developers are not threatened by AI, and developers are most frustrated by technical debt at work. On the topic of AI, 76% of respondents shared they are using or planning to use AI tools, but only 43% said they trust the accuracy of AI tools and 45% believe AI tools struggle to handle complex tasks.
item.author: (Erin Yepis)
